poem:
"Ode to the Unkept Promise"

Landlord's will, a clenched fist, a closed door.
Manifesto pledges, now unhusked seeds, no more. 
Evictions echo, Tory footsteps on the floor.
Four cold winters divulge the sore. 

Nestled dreams in rented corners, quashed,
Against the tide of unkept words, tenants washed.
In the broken rhythm of the betrayed, 
The forgotten music of justice frayed.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Guardian view on tenants’ rights: the Tories have betrayed renters | Editorial More than four years ago, the 2019 Conservative manifesto pledged to abolish no-fault evictions in England, in an effort to make tenancies more secure and remove the right of private landlords to evict people from their homes at will. In the past few years, a huge campaigning effort went into ensuring that this commitment would be kept. Last week, it became clear". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
